channel.description:

So, why do you believe?

item.title: Christianity
item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah
item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:101, topic:250509”][quote author=Elijah link=topic=330388.msg2835300#msg2835300 date=1245609600]
I know more than what can be said in texts, or communicated. I’ve got wisdom, experiences that can’t be explained. Whether you believe me or not, I believe they happened. I may be a lunatic in your eyes. But as long as I am breathing, and have the ability to speak, I will profess my faith.
[/quote]

Elijah (I just keep on hammering on you, don’t I), you keep on talking about experiences that can’t be explained. By those experiences, you talk about feelings of joy, recognition, or anything? If that’s true, please consider my explanation of those feelings. (If you don’t mean that by experiences, please elaborate.)

When you go to a doctor, you know he is properly educated and knows what he’s doing. You have faith in him. If he gives you medication, you know it will help. If I gave you the same medication, you would be hesitating whether you should take it or not.

If you have small, unexplainable pains, the doctor probably thinks you have a serious case of being a whiny ass. But he doesn’t tell you that. He listens to you very careful, and comes up with a cure. He sends you to the pharmacy with a prescription. The pharmacist gives you a nice box saying Salsolutinsolusal. Once you arrive at your house, you eat two pills as prescribed. You do this twice a day, for a week. After a few days you start to feel good. You think that the pills did their job. But did they? Weren’t those pills simple placebo’s?

Why can’t the same apply to praying? You believe that someone listens to you, so it makes you feel good.[/quote]

This whole situation you described would make sense, for someone who doesn’t go to church for the right reasons. The ones that go to use it as a social hour. Meet the golf buddies, etc.

I, unlike many other people, would do research into what I was taking. I don’t follow blindly. If I get scripts from anyone other than a doctor. Of course I would be suspicious, even if it’s my own drug dealer. Even if I’ve known him for years, I’m still going to be cautious. But a doctor, I’m going to have some faith in them, because of their education. Just as I would have faith in a repairman, to repair my television properly.

But because I’m paranoid and have very little trust in anyone, I would still be cautious of them, regardless of their education. The difference between myself and the masses, is education. I’ve educated myself in certain areas. Just as you all have, and other intelligent people have.

Those experiences I was talking about didn’t exactly pertain to praying. More like events in my life that seem unexplainable. Which sure, anyone else would take it immediately as a sign of some sort, superstition. But I do research, I try and find a way to explain it. And When I can’t find an answer, or the answer is shown to me. Then I know it was God.

When I pray, I follow a certain order in my prayers. Firstly I ask for forgiveness of my sins. Second I worship him. And third I pray for needs that I need met. That’s how I pray. And my needs are always met, whether that be financially, or anything of the sort. I’m not saying it was miraculous what takes place, but it could be considered a miracle.

There’s a study of the bible, about sowing and reaping. And what it means to sow and reap. This is usually used by those scam artists to steal a bunch of money off of unsuspecting folks. But there’s a lot of truth in these verses and the study over them. When I give money for something, I am sowing money into something. When I get the item I paid money for, I’m reaping what I’ve sown.

It may not be so amazing and miraculous. But by sowing seed money into a $.99 cheeseburger, I’ve reaped a cheeseburger. That’s short term sowing and reaping. Let’s say God told me that someone needed money. So I, following God’s orders, I give a specific amount of money to a person. Not saying God gives me a specific amount, but I give what I feel is right.

That act is again, sowing. When this person gets the money, they may sow it into areas of their own. I may or may not have any yield from what I’ve sown, but by sowing money I have faith in God. It’s possible this person wasn’t saved before, but this act of kindness from a random stranger, gets them saved. That is what I’ve reaped.

So by giving a little bit of money to a person in need, and that person getting saved. That’s a miracle in my eyes. It may not be the definition of a miracle, but still. I’ve also had miraculous things happen to me as well.

That all really explains what happens when I pray. That doesn’t always happen, but it’s an example. So it shows that God listens. You may call it all circumstantial, but I don’t believe it is.
